title: 105_hr4087
content: The Act may be cited as the "Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act Amendments of 1998". Congress finds that Indian tribes and Alaska Native organizations participating in programs under the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 have improved services, increased employment for American Indians, assisted welfare recipients, and shown the value of integrating education, employment, and training services. The initiative under the Act should be strengthened to emphasize these programs. The Indian tribes and Alaska Native organizations have improved services and increased employment through programs under the Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992. The initiative should be strengthened by including all programs that emphasize the value of work within a demonstration program. The Office of Self-Governance of the Department of the Interior should implement these programs. The Indian tribes and Alaska Native organizations have benefited from programs under the Indian Employment, Training, and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992. The Department of the Interior and other Federal agencies should support programs emphasizing the value of work for American Indians and Alaska Natives. AMENDMENTS TO THE INDIAN EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING AND RELATED SERVICES DEMONSTRATION ACT OF 1992. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is being amended to redefine "Federal agency" and specify the programs affected by the amendments. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is being amended to include programs related to securing, retaining, or creating employment opportunities for Indian tribes. This includes the general assistance program and the Johnson-O'Malley Program. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is being amended to include educational services for elementary and secondary school students of Indian tribes. Amendments also involve changing references from "department" to "agency" and adding the ability to waive statutory requirements for plan approval. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is being amended to include job creation activities and employment opportunities, with provisions for waivers and reconsideration of disapprovals. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is amended to allow tribal governments to use funds for creating employment opportunities, with a determination based on unemployment rates. Federal responsibilities under the Act are also revised. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is amended to allow tribal governments to use funds for creating employment opportunities, with a determination based on unemployment rates. Amendments include changing "Bureau of Indian Affairs" to "Office of Self-Governance" and adding provisions for project approval by Indian tribes. Additionally, a new requirement is added for the convening of lead agency officials and representatives of Indian tribes involved in demonstration projects. The Director of the Office of Self-Governance of the Department of the Interior will ensure an orderly transfer of lead agency functions under the Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 to the Office. The Office of Self-Governance will oversee the transfer of lead agency functions from the Bureau of Indian Affairs to ensure no adverse effects on participating Indian tribes. Personnel and resources will be transferred as deemed appropriate by the Secretary of the Interior within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 19. CONSOLIDATED ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is amended to include a Consolidated Advisory Committee. SEC. 19. CONSOLIDATED ADVISORY COMMITTEE. Federal agencies must allow tribal governments to establish a consolidated advisory committee to oversee integrated programs. Waivers may be granted to bypass requirements for separate advisory committees. The Indian Employment, Training and Related Services Demonstration Act of 1992 is amended to allow Alaska Native villages or corporations to carry out projects through a regional consortium. Withdrawal from participation is permitted.
